title: Prince Abdullah's Bin Laden link has 'hurt reputation of Sheffield United'
text:
Sheffield United's reputation with the banks has been damaged by the connection between owner Prince Abdullah and the Bin Laden family, a court has been told.

The High Court heard on Monday how the Santander Bank demanded answers after the revelations made during the course of a long-running and bitter co-ownership dispute between the Saudi royal and long-standing former chairman Kevin McCabe.

‘The resulting publicity has been highly damaging to the club,’ said Andreas Gledhill QC, as he addressed the court on behalf of the prince on the matter of legal costs. It had been ‘confusing and distressing for fans,’ he said, and had ‘led to some difficulties with the bankers Santander’.

Prince Abdullah has been involved in dispute with Sheffield United co-owner Kevin McCabe

The Bin Laden connection emerged during a six-week long High Court trial in the summer when it became clear Prince Abdullah had borrowed money from Saleh Bin Laden through his connections in Saudi Arabia to help the club through cash-flow problems in 2018.

He went on to speak in support of the Bin Laden family at a press conference in Sheffield last month shortly after Mr Justice Fancourt had ruled in his favour in the complicated ownership case and dismissed allegations of bribery against him. McCabe was ordered to sell his 50 per cent stake in the club to the prince for £5million.

In return, Prince Abdullah was given until next summer to purchase from McCabe various properties, including the stadium at Bramall Lane and the club’s training ground and academy, thought to be worth around £50m.

The Saudi prince became involved with the Blades when the club were in League One in 2013

Justice Fancourt also ruled broadly in favour of the prince when it came to costs on Monday and will consider indemnity costs for him in view of the ‘extremely serious’ bribery allegations which took up so much prominence in the case against him and were found to have ‘no proper foundation’.

He rejected McCabe’s right to appeal his verdict in the High Court but the case will drag on with McCabe set to take it to the Court of Appeal. The judge has retired to look into McCabe’s efforts to safeguard his stake in the club should his appeal be upheld.

‘As matters stand the club is going to be sailing quite close to the wind,’ said Paul Downes QC, representing McCabe.

Mr Downes explained how the Blades would be expected to pay £20m for goalkeeper Dean Henderson in June, at the end of his loan from Manchester United, and how players will share a £10m bonus if they avoid relegation.
description: Sheffield United's reputation with the banks has been damaged by the connection between owner Prince Abdullah and the Bin Laden family, a court has been told.
authors: Matt Barlow For The Daily Mail
